metadata.case_name: Lalji Raja and Sons of Bankura v. Hansraj Nathu Ram

facts.text: Decree-holders obtained a decree against the respondents in the court of Sub-Judge, Bankura, West Bengal for a sum of over Rs. 12,000/-, on December 3, 1949.

On March 28, 1950 decree-holders applied to the Bankura court to transfer the decree together with a certificate of non-satisfaction to the court at Morena in the then Madhya Bharat State for execution. It was ordered accordingly.
Execution proceedings commenced in the court of Additional District Judge at Morena on September 21, 1950, Money Execution Case No. 8 of 1950.

Judgment-debtors resisted execution on ground that court had no jurisdiction as decree was of a foreign court and passed ex parte. Court accepted contention and dismissed execution petition on December 29, 1950.
On April 1, 1951 the Code of Civil Procedure Amendment Act, Act 11 of 1951 came into force, extending the Code to the former State of Madhya Bharat.
Decree-holders appealed against Morena court's dismissal to Madhya Pradesh High Court, which allowed the appeal. Judgment-debtors appealed to Supreme Court.

Supreme Court allowed judgment-debtors' appeal and restored Morena court's order, reported in Hansraj Nathu Ram v. Lalji Raj and sons of Bankura, 1963 2 S.C.R. 619, rendered on April 30, 1962. Ruled transfer by Bankura court was without jurisdiction as Code did not apply to Morena court then.
On February 15, 1963, decree-holders filed another execution case before Bankura court praying for transfer of decree to Morena court.
Bankura court ordered transfer of decree to Morena court.
Execution proceedings started afresh in Morena court on August 31, 1963, Execution Case No. 1 of 1963.
Judgment-debtors resisted execution on grounds: (a) barred by res judicata; (b) barred by s. 48 CPC; (c) barred by limitation; (d) decree not executable as of foreign court.

Judgment-debtors appealed to Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 20 of 1964. High Court held execution not barred by res judicata, s.48 or limitation, but decree not executable as of foreign court, relying on Shitole case. Judgment dated August 27, 1964.
Decree-holders filed appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.
Decree was ex parte; judgment-debtors served with notice but did not appear; cause of action arose within Bankura court's jurisdiction.

legal_issues.text: Whether the decree under execution is not executable by courts situate in the area comprised in the former State of Madhya Bharat
Whether the decree is barred by S. 48 of the Code

petitioner_arguments.text: Decree in question is not a decree of a foreign court as contemplated by the Code; Morena court is a court as contemplated by ss. 38 and 39 CPC; no valid objection to execution in Morena court.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 38, 39 CPC; definition of foreign court in s.2(5) CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Previous execution proceedings prosecuted with due diligence and good faith, became infructuous for want of jurisdiction; s.48 limitation extended under s.14(2) Limitation Act 1908.

respondent_arguments.text: Decree under execution being a decree of a foreign court is a nullity qua courts in former State of Madhya Bharat; not executable in Morena court.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.13 CPC; Shitole case; Sirdar Gurdval Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote; Private International Law

respondent_arguments.text: Execution barred by res judicata, s.48 CPC, limitation.
Non-executability of decree in Madhya Bharat is a vested right protected by s.20(1)(b) CPC Amendment Act 1951.
S.48 prescribes a bar, not period of limitation; cannot take benefit of s.14(2) Limitation Act.

court_reasoning.text: Bankura court not a foreign court under s.2(5) CPC (either pre- or post-1951 definition); decree not foreign decree; s.13(b) not applicable as not foreign judgment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judgment-debtors served notice, did not appear; no violation of natural justice.

court_reasoning.text: Ex parte decree by court with jurisdiction over cause of action (s.20(c) CPC) valid; not nullity outside its country unless local law denies; executable under ss.38,39 CPC now that Code applies to Morena court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transfer valid post-1951 extension of Code.

court_reasoning.text: Shitole case inapplicable: there Gwalior court not under Code; here Bankura court always under Code.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decree passed under Code; transfer to court now under Code.

court_reasoning.text: Non-executability pre-1951 not a vested right or privilege under s.20(1)(b) CPC Amendment Act; relates to jurisdiction/procedure, not substantive right of JD.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Extension of Code remedied jurisdictional defect.

court_reasoning.text: S.48 prescribes period of limitation, controlled by Limitation Act 1908 (Arts 181,182,183; cl.(b) s.48(2)); exclusion under s.14(2) applicable; previous proceedings diligent, good faith, infructuous for want of jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Courts unanimous post-conflict; later Limitation Act 1963 confirms by replacing s.48 with Art.136.

holdings.text: Decree not foreign decree; transfer to Morena court valid under ss.38,39 CPC; executable.
Execution not barred by s.48 CPC; time excluded under s.14(2) Limitation Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hansraj Nathu Ram v. Lalji Raj and sons of Bankura
precedents_cited.relevance: Transfer without jurisdiction pre-1951 as Code not applicable to Morena court then.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rai Rajendra Sardar Maloji Narsingh Rao Shitole v. Sri Shankar Saran
precedents_cited.relevance: Decree by Gwalior court (foreign) nullity; inapplicable here as Bankura court under Code.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sirdar Gurdval Singh v. The Rajah of Faridkote
precedents_cited.relevance: Ex parte foreign decree nullity internationally unless submitted or local legislation; qualified by local law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kishendas v. Indo Carnatic Bank Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Separate opinion clarifies no conflict; transfer invalid on date there.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines foreign court/judgment; executability and transfer of decrees; jurisdiction over cause of action.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure Amendment Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended Code to Madhya Bharat; savings clause does not protect non-executability as vested right.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: 12-year bar for execution treated as limitation period, exclusion under Limitation Act.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Exclusion of time for defective proceedings; periods for execution applications.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Replaced s.48 CPC, confirming it as limitation.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; executing court's order restored; directed to proceed with execution; respondents to pay costs in Supreme Court and High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Execution to proceed in Morena court
outcome.costs: Respondents to pay costs of appellants in this Court and High Court

key_quotes.text: "a decree pronounced in absentem by a foreign Court, to the jurisdiction of which the Defendant has not in any way submitted himself, is by international law an absolute nullity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Qualified by local legislation like CPC s.20(c); not absolute here.

key_quotes.text: "the decree which could be transferred has to be a decree passed under the Code and the Court to which it could be transferred has to be a Court which was governed by the Indian Code of Civil Procedure."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Hansraj case; satisfied now post-1951.

key_quotes.text: "S. 48 of the Code is controlled by the provisions of the Limitation Act, 1908."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Resolves s.48 as limitation, allows s.14(2) exclusion.
